title: Heinrich Kaspar Schmid
text:
Heinrich Kaspar Schmid (11 September 1874 – 8 January 1953) was a German <a href="composer">composer</a>.
Biography.
Schmid was born at <a href="Landau">Landau</a>.
As a boy he studied music with his father who was a school teacher and choral conductor. He also sang in the boys choir at <a href="Regensburg%20Cathedral">Regensburg Cathedral</a> for several years. He entered the <a href="Munich%20Akademie%20der%20Tonkunst">Munich Akademie der Tonkunst</a> where he studied composition with <a href="Ludwig%20Thuille">Ludwig Thuille</a>. In 1905 he was appointed to teach at the <a href="Munich%20Academy">Munich Academy</a> and in 1919 was promoted to a full professor. After <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Schmid entered a highly successful part of his career both as a performer and composer. He toured throughout <a href="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>, and <a href="Russia">Russia</a>. In 1921 he became director of the <a href="Karlsruhe%20Conservatory">Karlsruhe Conservatory</a> and assumed the directorship of the <a href="Augsburg%20Music%20School">Augsburg Music School</a> [now Conservatory] in 1924. He retired from academic work in 1932.
He died at <a href="Geiselbullach">Geiselbullach</a>, near <a href="Munich">Munich</a>, in 1953.
Work.
Stylistically, Schmid's compositions were more in keeping with the late-<a href="romantic%20music">Romantics</a> than with 20th-century innovations. <a href="Brahms">Brahms</a> in particular had a major influence on Schmid's compositional sensibility. This is particularly evident in the <a href="sonatas">sonatas</a> for violin and piano (1920, 1939). His best work is probably his "Symphony in D Minor" (1947) which was admired for its fresh and accomplished treatment of traditional musical materials. Elements of Bavarian <a href="folk%20music">folk music</a> appear in the rural <a href="mass%20%28music%29">mass</a> settings, <a href="choral">choral</a> compositions, "<a href="lieder">lieder</a>," <a href="chamber%20works">chamber works</a>, and his <a href="opera">opera</a> "Finden und Meiden".
